Someone does the classic magic trick of pretending to take something out of their ear (such as a coin). Or maybe it is a cigarette or a pen that you take from behind the ear (the crotch of the ear).

Show on Jisho
886
恥
shame
This chinese character explains how shame stands between social expectations (the *ear* listening to the outside world) and one's own expectations (one's *heart*).
Show on Jisho

職
post
Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!
Show on Jisho
888
聖
holy
The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his *ear* to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his *mouth* to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, *king*s are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).
Show on Jisho
889
敢
daring
Only a truly #daring# Japanese student would wear a *spike* in his *ear* under the gaze of the Japanese teacher *taskmasters*!
Show on Jisho
890
聴
listen
Listening to others is different from hearing [1626] with the *ear*. One must allow the words to pierce through the *eyes* (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the *heart*...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You're not listening to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said..." “Yes, but you're not listening."
Show on Jisho
891
懐
pocket
(re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York *State of Mind*": you need *ten* *eyes* to make sure no one will go through your *garments* and pick your pockets
Show on Jisho
892
慢
ridicule(mandala)
I'll focus on the #mandala# primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it's the "man" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the *sun* representing the cosmos, the *eye* represents the human observer, the *crotch* represents the animal instincts.
Show on Jisho
893
漫
loose(manga)
One obscure Tibetan sect-- the Otaku cult-- has an unusually loose interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas (漫画). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew.
Show on Jisho
894
買
buy
When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and buy before anybody else does.
Show on Jisho
895
置
placement
Working in retail you learn the placement of any item should be at *eye* level so it's seen *straightaway*
Show on Jisho
896
罰
penalty
For Japanese, when the mind's eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I'm sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I'm sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ)
Show on Jisho
897
寧
rather
A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d'oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I'd RATHER not."
Show on Jisho
898
濁
voiced
The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who's venom is dripping like water from her fangs.

ring
The Saudi woman accepted the marriage ring, though it meant lowering her eyes to the floor and covering her mouth with a scarf.

Retainer = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.

Slaves are being paraded, decorated with flowers in a rather ironic attempt of making them look happy in order to attract buyers. After the parade they are put back into the storehouse. - STOREHOUSE (for temporary preservation), storeroom

The slave reclines on the floor at night to watch the stars. Since that's the only thing the slave is allowed to “read”, he does so very thoroughly and diligently, hence perusal.

The letter E, with a GIGANTIC middle stroke.

Show on Jisho
922

power
Perhaps KA is the most POWERful of all the katakana... Because the Japanese chose it to symbolize POWER.
Show on Jisho
923
男

Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.

labor
Hard labor is like a *schoolhouse* for your *muscles*

The necromancer hangs out at the local *graveyard* and uses his dark *powers* to recruit an army of undead. Emphasize the verb form to keep distinct from the noun {1173}.
Show on Jisho

I have an inferiority complex because I have *few muscles*! (Image: Arnold laughing at a weakling on the beach with few muscles).

The great #achievement#s of humankind, were *crafts* completed by *muscle power*: the pyramids, the Eiffel tower, etc.

Only the #power#ful can persuade #Pegasus# to let them ride her.

Guy + Power: the average *guy* has to toil very hard for many years in order to reach a position of *power* in the company.

勃
uprising,suddenness
an erection can shoot like a *needle* from its *crown* and has the *power* to make a *child*
Show on Jisho
931
励
encourage
*10,000* Persians are at the base of the *cliff*, but the leader of the 300 Spartans just flexes his huge *muscles* and encourages his men by shouting that they have the *power* to fight them all.
Show on Jisho
932
加
add
To add *muscle* mass it's important to put protein in your *mouth* after working out.
Show on Jisho
933
賀
congratulations
Congratulations are so much better when you *add money* to them.
Show on Jisho
934
架
erect
I'm not sure I know about erector sets or tinker toys but I do know about jenga. You play by taking *wooden* pieces from the middle of a wooden tower and *add*ing them to the top. In this way you erect a very unstable structure.
Show on Jisho
935
脇
armpit
Armpit is the *flesh* near your *tri*ceps.
Show on Jisho
936
脅
threaten
Compare the primitive positions of {870} and {871}. When your *triceps* rest alongside your *body*, they fit snugly against your #armpit#. When you hold them above your *body*, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.
Show on Jisho
937
協
co-
The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that *needle* (syringe) in your *triceps* won't hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji.
Show on Jisho
938
行
going
To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.
Show on Jisho
939
律
rhythm
Picture a school of studious calligraphers. All their *brushes* are moving up and down the *columns* at the same time, in beautiful rhythm.
Show on Jisho
940
復
restore
The *column* of soldiers has to *double back* to restore the peace in the village they just left.
Show on Jisho
941
得
gain
To gain more knowledge of what's goin on in the world I'm reading *column* after *column* of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I'm *glued* to it till *nightbreak*

従
accompany
The line of viking soldiers is always accompanied by a horn mending specialist

The junior employee is always *RUNNING* around *GOING* here and there for his superiors.

The COLUMNS of this TEMPLE are a well-know meeting spot. You can always see someone WAITING there.

journey
In Medieval Japan, *going* to see your *lord* was often a long journey.

947
径
diameter
Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a *line* of thread off a humongous *spool* until it got to the other side.
Show on Jisho
948
彼
he
The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (*column*), and he wears a ragged *pelt* as his only clothing. To remember the *column*, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.
Show on Jisho
949
役
duty
Japanese kamikaze pilots (and the American from Dr. Strangelove) are so devoted to their duty that they *go* with their *missiles*.
Show on Jisho
950
徳
benevolence
Benevolence: *going* to help those who are unable to *listen* (i.e. have no ears).
Show on Jisho
951
徹
penetrate
The *taskmistress* in a moment of weakness allowed the man's *column* to penetrate her. As punishment he was made to *bring up* their infant.
Show on Jisho
952
徴
indications
If you see a *column* of *kings* being marched up the *mountain* under a *taskmaster*'s whip... indications are, there has been a coup.
Show on Jisho
953
懲
penal
Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart (learned one's lesson). Easily confused with {679} and {833}. Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system ("changing people's hearts" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there's no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one's bad experiences)
Show on Jisho
954
微
delicate
We're *going* up the *mountain* announces the *taskmaster*. Anyone with *legs* too delicate must stay behind
Show on Jisho
955
街
boulevard
The boulevard of boulevards, the *Champs Elysées*, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in *ivy* to give the champions a heroes' welcome.
Show on Jisho
956
桁
girder
When the *wooden* #girders# start to snap, the workmen shout "Run! Let's *go!*"
Show on Jisho
957
衡
equilibrium
To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the *brains* of citizens are *bound up* (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like *St. Bernard's dogs* put alongside the *boulevards*.
Show on Jisho
958
稿
draft
Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the *tall* *wheat*
Show on Jisho
959
稼
earnings
Your #earnings# allow you to bring *home* your daily bread (made of *wheat*, naturally).
Show on Jisho

程
extent
The extent to which some people will go to create '*wheat displays*', or as some call them 'crop circles', is truly amazing.

tax
This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.

962
稚
immature
#Immature# *turkeys* are stuffed with *wheat* to make it look bigger.
Show on Jisho
963
和
harmony
What better image of harmony and peace than relaxing amidst the wheat, with one long stalk in your mouth.
Show on Jisho
964
移
shift
[+sweetnet] You're at your computer studying RTK, when all of a sudden you shift your bowl of *Cap'n Crunch cereal* and it spills all over the keyboard. It breaks your shift key! You hit it *many, many, many* times, and finally it begins to work again.
Show on Jisho
965
秒
second
An hourglass filled with *wheat* counts time. A *few* *wheat seeds* drop every second.
Show on Jisho
966
秋
autumn
in AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it's time to harvest it.
Show on Jisho
967
愁
distress
In AUTUMN, the farmer's HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!
Show on Jisho
968
私
private
A joke so bad as "wheatashi wa" deserves an elbow in the private parts.
Show on Jisho
969
秩
regularity
Eating plenty of *wheat* will improve regularity and help you *lose* weight.
Show on Jisho
970
秘
secret
A young couple meets in secret in the *wheat* field because their families are enemies. They *cross their hearts* and swear eternal - even if secret - love. Do not confuse with {775}
Show on Jisho
971
称
appellation
*WHEAT* that is *RECLINING* and *LITTLE* (*small*) can't get the *APPELLATION* "quality wheat".
Show on Jisho
972
利
profit
1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!
Show on Jisho
973
梨
pear tree
Japanese pears (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyrus_pyrifolia) are very tasty fruits and frequently used as a gift in Japan. They are quite expensive, so you can assume that a farmer can make a good *profit* from these fruits after getting them from the *tree*.
Show on Jisho
974
穫
harvest
Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.
Show on Jisho
975
穂
ear of a plant
The pilgrims only had *wheat*, so they asked the Indians to do them a *favor* and trade them for some #ears# of corn.
Show on Jisho
976
稲
rice plant
The rice plant evolved from wheat in olden times to defend itself against vultures eating it - rice causes vultures to explode.
Show on Jisho
977
香
incense
If we would throw a huge amount of wheat on top of the sun, would it become a galactic incense? Maybe then aliens wouls come more often, enjoying the incense.
Show on Jisho

季
seasons
There's a season for planting wheat and there's mating season for having children.

committee
While the men had to harvest the field, *the women* formed committee where they decided what to do with *the wheat*. Here you see one of them carrying some of it away.

excel
The icon of the Special edition of Microsoft Excel for Farmers shows a *fist* holding *wheat*.

透
transparent
If you *excel* in the *Mario Kart road*, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a *transparent* racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4

entice
*Word* and *Excel* somehow manage to entice people to use them, despite their plethora of bugs.
Show on Jisho
983
稽
training
The hardest part of my training as a cook was when they gave me some *wheat* and a *chihuahua with a human leg* and said, "Now make something *delicious*". Why 16 strokes? I think that it has 15 strokes
Show on Jisho
984
穀
cereals
There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has *samurai* cereal. Great Britain has *Crowned Wheat* ... the United States and Russia have *Missile* cereals
Show on Jisho
985
菌
germ
can also mean bacteria.....imagine the *wheat pent in your fridge* growing to the point where they resemble *flowers*.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-)
Show on Jisho
986
萎
numb(fade away)
The keyword numb makes no sense. I choose 萎む（しぼむ）"#to fade away#". A *girl* lies in a *wheat* field at the same time every day. A photo is taken every day showing this scene and a time lapse video shows the wheat growing through the year until the wheat is tall and the top sprouts to look like its *flowers*. At this point, the girl can no longer be seen in the photos and she #fades away#.
Show on Jisho
987
米
rice
Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA
Show on Jisho
988
粉
flour
Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is #flour#. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...)
Show on Jisho
989
粘
sticky
Despite Heisig's warnings against this form of thinking, this is one of those rare kanjis that makes a good pictogram. Think of sticky as in sticky mochi paste, which is traditionally made by dropping rice in a bucket and pounding it with a mallet. So, you have the rice on the left, and on the right you have the mallet poised over the bucket. Nuff said.
Show on Jisho
990
粒
grains
A sage is using *rice* to fill up a *vase*, but as an exercise in patience, he's doing it #grain# by #grain#.
Show on Jisho
991
粧
cosmetics
Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT ('cause it's darker) used in the past.
Show on Jisho
992
迷
astray
If you go astray, just follow the *rice* you dropped along the *road* to find your way back.
Show on Jisho
993
粋
chic
*Americans* think that tattoos with Chinese characters are chic, but *nine* out of *ten* times they end up with something trivial tattooed on their arm, like *rice*.
Show on Jisho
994
謎
riddle
The *words* 言 of a riddle are deliberately designed to lead you *astray* 迷. 謎、なぞ, riddle; 謎を解く、〜をとく, to answer a riddle: 彼はその謎を解く鍵を捜し出した, "He searched for the key to answer the riddle." 被害者の死因は警察にとって謎です, "The victim's cause of death is a riddle to the police."
Show on Jisho
995
糧
provisions
Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same *quantity* of *rice*. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing *quantity* and the nuance of food "rations", "food supply": the kanji also appears in "military provisions" and "army rice")
Show on Jisho
996
菊
chrysanthemum
History: “Around the 8th century A.D., the chrysanthemum appeared in Japan. So taken were the Japanese with this flower that they adopted a single flowered chrysanthemum as the crest and official seal of the Emperor. Japan also has a National Chrysanthemum Day, which is called the Festival of Happiness.” Mnemonic: *flower* that looks like a lot of *grains* *bound* together.
Show on Jisho
997
奥
core
In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It's very dangerous, so they've trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he's adding more drops of rice as necessary.
Show on Jisho

number
Young *taskmaster* is learning #numbers# by watching *women* haul sacks of *rice* past him. "One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!"

類
sort

Show on Jisho
1008
笑
laugh
Tip: 天 and 夭 (*heavens* and *sapling*) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing *angel* 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369). Story: The fully-grown *bamboo* trees are laughing at the little *sapling*.
Show on Jisho

笠

The *bamboo* *vase* was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn't know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat.

笹
bamboo grass
“One of the most attractive aspects of bamboo is that it is a renewable resource; it takes less than a year for a stalk to reach maturity, compared to the decades for most trees, whether needle or broadleaf.” -- Mnemonic : "bamboo grass is the next *bamboo generation*".

The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the *bamboo* pieces *fit together*.

肉
meat
Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
Show on Jisho
1099
腐
rot
The #rotting# *meat* *adheres* to the *cave* walls.
Show on Jisho
1100
座
sit
Coal mine (*cave*); tea break time; the *assembly line* stops and everyone sit or squat on the *dirt* floor, in a long line, to rest
Show on Jisho
1101
挫
sprain
I #sprained# my *fingers* when I *sat in meditation* (by sitting in a strange position)
Show on Jisho
1102
卒
graduate
In the distant future, universities will produce graduates on *assembly lines*. As the kids move along on a conveyor belt they are injected with knowledge via a *needle* from below while overhead robotic arms place *square caps with tassels* on their heads. This way it only takes a few minutes to graduate.
Show on Jisho
1103
傘
umbrella
There are two *assembly lines* at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. The two lines *cross* at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.
Show on Jisho
1104
匁
monme
"Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!" "Yeah man, it's a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"
Show on Jisho
1105
以
by means of
A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.
Show on Jisho
1106
似
similar
A PERSON can become quite SIMILAR to someone else BY MEANS OF plastic surgery.
Show on Jisho
1107
併
join
*Zoro* furiously works a *puzzle* in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society.
Show on Jisho
1108
瓦
tile
Horror scene: Hanging from the *ceiling*, a *plough* and *fishhook* *dripping* with blood down onto the #tile#d bathroom floor.
Show on Jisho
1109
瓶
flower pot
A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
Show on Jisho
1110
宮

A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, Shinto shrine"!
Show on Jisho

occupation
Stay in school so you can get an occupation that doesnt require breaking your backbone all day.
Show on Jisho
1112
善
virtuous
Imagine a priest's teaching: "To achieve #virtue# one must first submit himself as a *sheep* to God's flock, rejecting the *horns* of Satan and resisting the *mouth* of Hell.
Show on Jisho
1113
膳
dining tray
as VIRTUOUS cannibals, we serve FLESH on DINING TRAYS
Show on Jisho
1114
年
year
A #horse# wears a #monocle# for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like {1308}
Show on Jisho
1115
夜
night
Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite "walking legs." It's a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: *evening* plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the *top hat* which *Zoro* is wearing out on the town...
Show on Jisho
1116
液
fluid
I imagined some kind of liquid (*water*) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at *night*, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?
Show on Jisho
1117
塚
hillock
These *pigs* are searching for truffles in the hillocks. Their noses track the *dirt*, and the one who finds the biggest truffles are *crown*ed, never to be eaten.
Show on Jisho
1118
幣
cash
A counterfeiter is using a *shredder* to shred a *towel* in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) .
Show on Jisho
1119
蔽
cover over
See why the FLOWERS keep on falling into the SHREDDER? You keep on forgetting to put the COVER OVER it. After you finished with it dont forget to put the COVER over it so that the FLOWERS wont fall into it again.
Show on Jisho
1120
弊
abuse
Shoving someone's *hands* into a *shredder* surely counts as abuse.
Show on Jisho
1121
喚
yell
The musher yells at the 4 dogs bound up to the dog sled to get them to run faster and cross the finish line first. (4 St Bernards bound up together makes a dog sled)
Show on Jisho
1122
換
interchange
After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling *four bound up St. Bernard dogs*: one snap of your *fingers* and they interchange their positions.
Show on Jisho
1123
融
dissolve
Just one single mouthful of cola has enough acidic power to dissolve 4 nails and one large live insect! Gross! (Not actually true, but meh...)
Show on Jisho
1124
施
alms
Under their *banner*, volunteers are requesting alms for *scorpion* sting victims.
Show on Jisho
1125
旋
rotation
I had trouble remember this with previous zoo-banner-rotation stories, so here is something a bit more vivid: The future of ZOO technology: There is a giant Ferris Wheel-type contraption with individual plastic cages, each with an animal that ROTATES every 10 minutes. It's built half-way into the ground, can you envision it? The lazy people who watch wouldn't know what animal was what without the colorful BANNERS that accompany each cage.
Show on Jisho
1126
遊
play
The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.
Show on Jisho
1127
旅
trip
After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.
Show on Jisho
1128
勿
not
This kanji is NOT a piglett
Show on Jisho
1129
物
thing
A *cow* is *not* a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
Show on Jisho
1130
易
easy
The *sun* is *not* an easy place to get to. Kerbal space program 91050m/s !
Show on Jisho

賜
grant
If you want *money* the *easy* way get a grant

animals use urine as a "watery flag"

A #nun# *sits* in protests under an *American flag*.
Show on Jisho
1134
尻
buttocks
I wonder if this story will be *flagged* for saying i give her buttocks a score of *9*.
Show on Jisho
1135
泥
mud
Jesus can turn *water* into wine. When *nuns* try, all they can make is mud.
Show on Jisho
1136
塀
fence
[fence; wall; (kokuji)] A #fence# separates one *soil* from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of *soil*s in the world have a virtual #fence# called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their *soil* with one color, their national *flag* as the legend and a #fence# on the borders... don't you think it looks like a giant *puzzle*?
Show on Jisho
1137
履
footgear
after being embarassed at the olympics, the national track team wants to restore honor to their flag. So they hire Nike to create ultra futuristic footgear (think Michael Johnson's gold running shoes)
Show on Jisho
1138
屋
roof
In the *climax* of Rush Hour, Jackie Chan slides down a giant *flag* (a kanji flag, no less) from the roof.
Show on Jisho
1139
握
grip
fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.
Show on Jisho
1140
屈
yield
If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you.
Show on Jisho
1141
掘
dig
If you #dig# with your *fingers* hard enough, soil eventually *yields*.
Show on Jisho
1142
堀
ditch
(See {1061}). When *soil* finally *yielded* thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a #ditch#.
Show on Jisho
1143
居
reside
It is an *old* tradition that people plant a *flag* on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. {1064}
Show on Jisho
1144
据
set
The man #set# his *finger* firmly on the map and said "Here is where they *reside*, I am certain of it".
Show on Jisho
1145
裾
hem
Something is *residing* in the *hem* of your *cloak*. Maybe you should consider cleaning it? キョ コ すそ cuff; hem; foot of mountain
Show on Jisho
1146
層
stratum
The strata have piled up in an ever *increasing* pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they *flag* each stratum with the name of the corresponding era.
Show on Jisho

局
bureau
This is a Tourist Information Bureau. It has lots of national *flags* signs to indicate which languages are spoken/available and it stocks many *phrase*books.
Show on Jisho

slow
The traffic controller raises a flag that says: "*Sheep* on highway! Drive #slowly#."
Show on Jisho
1149
漏
leak
WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water.

We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.
Show on Jisho
1151
尺
shaku
Slang for blowjob and that's priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length
Show on Jisho
1152
尽
exhaust
A women is so exhausted by her "shakuhachi" that she needs to ice her jaw.
Show on Jisho
1153
沢
swamp
Different from {137} in that swamp has trees. The trees are represented by shakuhachi flutes here, mystically calling the water in like Pied Piper did to rats.
Show on Jisho
1154
訳
translate
You cannot pretend to translate into *words* the melody of the *shakuhachi*!
Show on Jisho
1155
択
choose
Depending on where you #choose# to put your *fingers*, the *shakuhachi* will produce a different note.
Show on Jisho
1156
昼
daytime
roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime
Show on Jisho
1157
戸
door
Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several *flags*, known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the *ceiling*.
Show on Jisho
1158
肩
shoulder
The shoulder is the best *part of the body* to bash a *door* open with (Don't ever try this. Use your foot).
Show on Jisho

房
tassel
Explanation here: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=14684#p14684
Show on Jisho
1160
扇
fan
It's insanely hot today! I'm standing in the *doorway*, fanning myself with *feathers*.
Show on Jisho
1161
炉
hearth
This hearth is equipped with a *fire*-proof *door*. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the *fire*-proof *door* keeping the *fire* behind, and nothing comes under the *door* primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.
Show on Jisho
1162
戻
re-
This is common with cats, but also happens with dogs. They go out the door. 5 minutes later they change their minds and come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. AAAAAARRRRRGGGHHHH!!!
Show on Jisho
1163
涙
tears
I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
Show on Jisho

雇
employ
Our company has no standards. We'll employ any *turkey* who walks in the *door*.
Show on Jisho

顧
look back
The people we employ(turkeys) are always turning their heads to look back. They don't want to be caught playing solitare on company time.

Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information.

A boy made an *altar*, but he's afraid to show it to God because he thinks it's *two little*.

As the priest salutes the congregation, he gets hooked up in the altar somehow, creating a quite embarrassing situation.
Show on Jisho
1169
祥
auspicious
Bringing a *sheep* to sacrifice on the *altar* was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive *sheep* for an offering.
Show on Jisho
1170
祝
celebrate
When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the *altar* at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a *teenager*.
Show on Jisho
1171
福
blessing
Put all your *wealth* on the church *altar* and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.)
Show on Jisho
1172
祉
welfare
Before it was the church, represented by the altar, that were responsible for welfare. It has now stopped and the state has taken over.
Show on Jisho
1173
社
company
An *altar* was bulldozed and filled with *soil* as the foundation for a new company building
Show on Jisho
1174
視
inspection
The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the *altar* a "visual once over" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?)
Show on Jisho
1175
奈
Nara
Besides the famous wooden Buddha, the city of Nara also has a famous St. Bernard on top of an alter in one of its temples.
Show on Jisho

Of course it had to be the military officer's idea to *glue* a *national flag* to the *altar* he's stationed at.

慰
consolation
A *military officer* must offer consolation to the *hearts* of the families of his fallen men.
Show on Jisho

款
goodwill
A popular samurai is on a party in the temple suddenly jumping on top of the altar letting out a big yawn. “Your goodwill from this temple is no more!”

prohibition
Placing trees on this alter is prohibited.
Show on Jisho
1180

collar
Dress code: all *cloaks* without collars are *prohibited*
Show on Jisho
1181
宗
religion
All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are #houses# where they place their #altars#.
Show on Jisho
1182
崇
adore
Several kanji become their 'greater' version when you add 山 on top (風 becomes 嵐, 石 becomes 岩). Thus, *religion* becomes #adoration#.
Show on Jisho
1183
祭
ritual
There are many famous penis #matsuri#s(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the *flesh* of the *crotch* on an *altar*.
Show on Jisho
1184
察
guess
Police (警察）drive around trying to guess whose house is having a matsuri(ritual) indoors after complaints from the neighbours
Show on Jisho
1185
擦
grate
if you mis-guess the cheese you'll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time)
Show on Jisho
1186
由
wherefore
"#Wherefore# art thou, *Sprouteo*?" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off)
Show on Jisho
1187
抽
pluck
If you pluck your *fingers*, new ones will *sprout* in their place. (try it ;)
Show on Jisho
1188
油
oil
The *liquid* oil that *sprouts* from an oil field
Show on Jisho
1189
袖
sleeve
The bad magician says, "As you can see, there's nothing up my sleeves!" Then he trips over his *cloak* and brussel *sprouts* fall everywhere.
Show on Jisho
1190
宙
mid-air
Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT
Show on Jisho
1191
届
deliver
There’s a flag sprouting up from the mail box when the mail is delivered. In the US.
Show on Jisho
1192
笛
flute
This is not as advanced as the shakuhachi flute, but a flute made of bamboo sprouts.
Show on Jisho
1193
軸
axis
An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a *car* going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single *sprout* (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.
Show on Jisho
1194
甲
armor
Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.
Show on Jisho
1195
押
push
Use your *fingers* to make sure the *roots* of your plant are deep underground by #pushing# them down, down, down. An ogre pushes some fingers down into the earth hoping they will make roots and grow new fingers.
Show on Jisho
1196
岬
headland
Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become *armoured mountains*. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an *armoured mountain*)
Show on Jisho
1197
挿
insert
"Armor broken. Please insert 1000 yen to repair armor". You then give your finger to the arcade game and leave.
Show on Jisho
1198
申
speaketh
I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a *cane* in their *mouth*.
Show on Jisho
1199
伸
expand
Zoro has been invited by Monkey D. Luffy to his Pirate Crews in order to expand it.
Show on Jisho
1200
神
gods
The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus' latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .
Show on Jisho
1201
捜
search
The *monkey* searches around with his *fingers* for his *crotch*.
Show on Jisho
1202

fruit
Just a pictogram of a cluster of fruit on a tree.

1203

confectionary
This candy is made in the shape of a *flower*, each petal with the taste of a different *fruit*.

課
chapter
After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of *fruit* to celebrate all the new *words* I've learned. (Thanks Misha!)

裸
naked
Eve was naked until she ate of the *fruit* and put a *cloak* on.

Pictograph, see book.
Show on Jisho
1207
