chop
We chop down *trees* with *axes* to #analyze# their rings.
Show on Jisho
1208
所
place
You outsiders better learn your place! An *axe* stuck in the *door* when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.
Show on Jisho
1209
祈
pray
A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the *altar*, his battle *axe* at the ready.
Show on Jisho
1210
近
near
The end is near. The *axe*-murderer is waiting for you on the *road*...
Show on Jisho
1211
折
fold
Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!
Show on Jisho
1212
哲
philosophy
A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are *folding* sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the *mouth* of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.
Show on Jisho
1213
逝
departed
The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the *roads* *folded* (from the earthquake).
Show on Jisho
1214
誓
vow
This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then *folded it into an origami*, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an *origami*, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the *folded words* are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an *origami* for the primitive "*fold*".
Show on Jisho
1215
斬
chop off
Picture a death-mobile car with rotating axes on the hood that drives by and chops off people's heads. [beheading is another common meaning]
Show on Jisho
1216
暫
temporarily
Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.
Show on Jisho
1217
漸
steadily
I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed *car*. First, they spray it with *water*; then, they use an *axe* to break through the window.
Show on Jisho
1218
断
severance
[Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some *rice* on a *fishhook* as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his *axe* and #sever# the line lest he be dragged into the depths.
Show on Jisho
1219
質
substance
What is this #substance# on this *clam*? I've already broken 2 *axes* on it! (Good #question#...質問)
Show on Jisho
1220
斥
reject
The quality expectations are very high in our *axe* manufacturing facility. If there's one *drop* of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.
Show on Jisho
1221
訴
accusation
*Words* of accusation are usually *rejected*, rarely accepted.
Show on Jisho
1222
昨
yesterday
Today I see. Yesterday I saw.
Show on Jisho
1223
詐
lie
Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a *word* of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the *saw* out again.
Show on Jisho
1224
作
make
*Zoro*'s favorite magazine is #Make#. He loves to #make# things. But he's a purist: he only uses *saws*, no power tools.
Show on Jisho
1225
雪
snow
SNOW isn't all that different from *RAIN*, except it can be removed with a *BROOM* because it only forms in freezing temperatures
Show on Jisho
1226
録
record
Historians have discovered an ancient record about Buddhist monastic life recorded in *gold* plates. Sadly, the only thing the monks did was use their *brooms* to sweep up *rice*.
Show on Jisho
1227
剥
peel off
A multi-purpose *broom*! It cleans, it sweeps (*rice*!), it hits! In fact, peel off the mahogany exterior to uncover a *sabre*! It slices, it dices, it kills!
Show on Jisho
1228
尋
inquire
The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ *ero* in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.)
Show on Jisho
1229
急
hurry
Fantasia: *Bound up brooms* out of control send Mickey's *heart* racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!
Show on Jisho
1230
穏
calm
The farmer is calm knowing that his *wheat* fields are protected from *vultures* by his *strawman* with a *heart* (all the better to do the job properly)
Show on Jisho
1231
侵
encroach
Zoro will hit you badly with a BROOM(because is katana is not necessary in this case) on your CROWN and your CROACH if you only attempt to ENCROACH his personal space
Show on Jisho
1232
浸
immersed
The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!)
Show on Jisho
1233
寝
lie down
After work, the *French maid* goes *home* and lies down with a *turtle*. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard...
Show on Jisho
1234
婦
lady
In high society, a lady is a *woman* who never touches a *broom* or an *apron*
Show on Jisho
1235
掃
sweep
sweep - Learn to sweep properly! Grip the *broom* with your *fingers* and be sure to wear your *apron*.
Show on Jisho
1236
当
hit
[hit; right; appropriate; himself] If you're old enough, this is a pictograph of an Atari joystick (which, BTW, got its name from this word/kanji).You can also think of how an Atari joystick is like a *small* *broom* with which you can #hit# and sweep off the enemies from the screen...
Show on Jisho
1237
彙
glossary
I was reading a recipe book but had trouble figuring out what a "pineapple" was. Thanks to the *one-way assisting* glossary at the end, I learnt that a pineapple was a *crowned fruit*.
Show on Jisho
1238
争
contend
This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to *bound up* his opponents, and with a *trident*, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific #contenders#, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.
Show on Jisho
1239
浄
clean
Separate the primitives. #Cleaning# the garden involves *watering* the lawn and *binding* up all the leaves with a *rake*.
Show on Jisho
1240
事
matter
This IS a laughing matter: *One mouth* getting smacked after someone steps on a *rake* - classic slapstick comedy!
Show on Jisho
1241
唐
T'ang
Some archaeologists are digging with a rake inside a cave believed to house remains from the T'ang dynasty, and one of them finds something and open his mouth wide.
Show on Jisho
1242
糖
sugar
Someone wants to make the tang drink more sweet with some sugar, but uses rice by a mistake.
Show on Jisho
1243
康
sane
A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with #ease#).
Show on Jisho
1244
逮
apprehend
The police have a new way of apprehending criminals; a big *sieve* in the *road*. Innocent people pass over, but people with a guilty conscience fall through.
Show on Jisho
1245
伊
Italy
Person from Italy
Show on Jisho
1246
君
old boy
Some seniors are doing what they have to do to a junior saying “Hey old boy, start mopping this floor” and sticking a mop into his mouth.
Show on Jisho
1247
群
flock
Some ‘old boys’ are flocking together like sheep (not unusual in Japan), standing in front of their senior who will share some life-secrets with them… “Old boys…”
Show on Jisho
1248
耐
-proof
I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.
Show on Jisho
1249
需
demand
If it's raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop.
Show on Jisho
1250
儒
Confucian
Confucian *persons demand* nothing. Except when the *rain* sets in. Then they need a *comb*. They are quite vain, you know...
Show on Jisho
1251
端
edge
Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is *standing* at the *edge* of a sheer *mountain* face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully *combing* his hair so it would fall perfectly.
Show on Jisho
1252
両
both
Primatives *celing; belt; mountain* as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the *celing* with your *belt* or jump off a *mountain*
Show on Jisho
1253
満
full
Add *water* THEN the *flowers*. With *both* the vase will be #full#.
Show on Jisho
1254
画
brush-stroke
To paint a kanji in your *ceiling* with only natural materials, you use a *sprout* as a #brush# and *shovel* some dirt to use as paint for your #strokes#. [modified from johnskb's]
Show on Jisho
1255
歯
tooth
*Stop* *shoveling* *rice* into your mouth, you'll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.
Show on Jisho
1256
曲
bend
It looks like the mouth of *Bender the robot*, from Matt Groening's animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character *Bender the robot* as a primitive.
Show on Jisho
1257
曹
cadet
*Bender* lasted just *one day* in the space cadets.
Show on Jisho
1258
遭
encounter
A random encounter! The *space cadet bender* meets his first enemies while flying around. What a surprise, as he thought those only happened while walking on the *roads* of the world map. You're usually safe while in a vehicle.
Show on Jisho
1259
漕
rowing
*Bender the cadet* (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of *water* (Bender is a robot).
Show on Jisho
1260
槽
vat
*Bender the Cadet* (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a *tree*, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69.
Show on Jisho
1261
斗
Big Dipper
Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of #measuring cup#. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.
Show on Jisho
1262
料
fee
When buying *rice*, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper *measuring cup*.
Show on Jisho
1263
科
department
University departments study things like *wheat* (agriculture) and the *big dipper* (physics/astronomy), and exact *measuring cups* (engineering).
Show on Jisho
1264
図
map
Can't see direct relation to {1177} since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.
Show on Jisho
1265
用
utilize
When your flesh is weak you must utilize a walking stick.
Show on Jisho
1266
庸
comfortable
To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.
Show on Jisho
1267
備
equip
An RPG where you're using *Zoro* as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the *flower cliff screwdriver*. This is a small *screwdriver* obtained at the bottom of a *cliff* that, when used in battle, shoots out pink *flowers*. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.
Show on Jisho
1268
昔
once upon a time
Once upon a time there was a McDonald's *salad* and it was left out in the sun for a whole *day*. But ... nothing happened because it was a McDonald's salad, chock full of preservatives and other garbage. The salad lived happily ever after (and so did the person who didn't eat it). The end. [I didn't write this... the original author deleted it... but it's my favourite story on the whole site.]
Show on Jisho
1269
錯
confused
*Once upon a time*, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into *gold*. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.)
Show on Jisho
1270
借
borrow
*Once upon a time* I let *Zoro* borrow my *salad* bowl, but he won't give it back. "This be mine now!"
Show on Jisho
1271
惜
pity
What a pity! My *state of mind* when i think of the opportunities I missed from *once upon a time*
Show on Jisho
1272
措
set aside
*Long ago* our ancestors #set aside# the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it's 昔 {1184} rather than 旧 {35} is that they began to use cutlery to eat *salad*. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in *Once upon a time*, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.)
Show on Jisho
1273
散
scatter
When his *salad* had *meat* in it, the vegetarian *taskmaster* blew his top and #scattered# it all over the restaurant floor.
Show on Jisho
1274
廿
twenty
*Ten* plus *ten* is twenty (see {28}).
Show on Jisho
1275
庶
commoner
If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.
Show on Jisho
1276
遮
intercept
If don't want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a *commoner* while traveling on the *road*.
Show on Jisho
1277
席
seat
Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches). [seat offerring intensified]
Show on Jisho
1278
度
degrees
The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.
Show on Jisho
1279
渡
transit
This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the *water* if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 *degrees*.
Show on Jisho
1280
奔
bustle
(note: easier way to remember haystack - it's just as difficult to find a needle in a haystack, even if you use two hands) Farmers hustling and bustling to move big haystacks.
Show on Jisho
1281
噴
erupt
History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the *mouths* of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting *haystacks* in the fields and the fisherman catching *shells* on the coast
Show on Jisho
1282
墳
tomb
Using *soil* and *hay* to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to #entomb# the Pharaohs along with all of their *money*.
Show on Jisho
1283
憤
aroused
Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn't seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry *state of mind* aroused at finding all your *clams* buried under your *haystack* stolen, gone!
Show on Jisho
1284
焼
bake
Ah, there's no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a *burning strawman*. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg
Show on Jisho
1285
暁
daybreak
The first person to see the *sun* at daybreak is of course the *straw man* who stands outside all *day*.
Show on Jisho
1286
半
half
Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.
Show on Jisho
1287
伴
consort
The *person* who is your consort is most commonly "your other *half*".
Show on Jisho
1288
畔
paddy ridge
A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF
Show on Jisho
1289
判
judgment
See book. Solomon made his judgment and decided to cut a baby in half with his saber. Good thing he found the real mom before that happened!
Show on Jisho
1290
拳
fist
Someone with a *quarter* in his *hand* is probably making a fist (either to protect the quarter or to make you guess which hand the quarter is in.)
Show on Jisho
1291
券
ticket
This kanji is used for coupon ticket, which cuts the price of an item down only by a *QUARTER* (25%), and the cutting down of the price is represented by the *DAGGER*.
Show on Jisho
1292
巻
scroll
At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only *25¢*. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous *snake*. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...
Show on Jisho
1293
圏
sphere
i assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the effect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done
Show on Jisho
1294
勝
victory
After your VICTORY cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.
Show on Jisho
1295
藤
wisteria
The wisteria is a type of hanging vine covered with *flowers*. By the light of the *quarter* *moon*, the *flowers* look like clusters of *rice grains*.
Show on Jisho
1296
謄
facsimilie
When you send a facsimile to the *moon* it costs a *quarter* per *word*.
Show on Jisho
1297
片
one-sided
Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn't see any trees or branches in there).
Show on Jisho
1298
版
printing block
Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn't be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. *One side* of the printing block would have a mirrored (*anti*) image of the kanji. This is true.
Show on Jisho
1299
之
of
Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.
Show on Jisho
1300
乏
destitution
Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny *drop* of a *building block* (LEGO) they are overjoyed.
Show on Jisho
1301
芝
turf
Artificial turf made easy: *flowers* stuck on top of *building blocks* that you can place anywhere.
Show on Jisho
1302
不
negative
*One below* zero is a negative number.
Show on Jisho
1303
否
negate
To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 {1217}: Note that ne*gate* contains 口, which is a kind of gate.
Show on Jisho
1304
杯
cupfuls
The maple #tree# is very #negative# about it, but the farmer still collects *cupfuls* of maple syrup from it.
Show on Jisho
1305
矢
dart
Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.
Show on Jisho
1306
矯
rectify
*Angels* have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop *darts* on those who misbehave... spare the *dart* and spoil the man...
Show on Jisho
1307
族
tribe
With a *banner* declaring "Keep Out!" and blow *darts* to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly.
Show on Jisho
1308
知
know
"You have a dart in your mouth!!" "...I know"
Show on Jisho
1309
智
wisdom
*Knowing* more each *day*, brings wisdom
Show on Jisho
1310
挨
shove(bar)
(+astridtops) In the crowded bar, someone shoves an *elbow* into you just as you are about to throw your *dart*. The *dart* slips from your *fingers*. You are just about to curse at the person when you realize that she is your Japanese teacher. You bow and greet [挨拶 (あいさつ): greeting, salutation] her instead. 挨拶回り (あいさつまわり): New Year courtesy calls 挨拶状 (あいさつじょう): greeting card
Show on Jisho
1311
矛
halberd
マオ Zedong always carried a halberd
Show on Jisho
1312
柔
tender
Use a *halberd* to tenderize a *tree*: *halberds* can chop, poke, and slash, so it's all good!
Show on Jisho
1313
務
task
So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your *halberd* to beat the *taskmaster* with the huge, bulging *muscles*.
Show on Jisho
1314
霧
fog
FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.
Show on Jisho
1315
班
squad
Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.
Show on Jisho
1316
帰
homecoming
A veteran returns home from battle. The village chief takes away his SPEAR to symbolize the end of fighting and gives him a BROOM and an APRON to begin his new career as a hotel maid. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran.
Show on Jisho
1317
弓
bow
My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
Show on Jisho
1318
引
pull
This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!
Show on Jisho
1319
弔
condolences
Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier's weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.
Show on Jisho
1320
弘
vast
If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance.
Show on Jisho
1321
強
strong
An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.
Show on Jisho
1322
弥
more and more
More and more *bows* were made to kill people, until they were *laid down* for better *small*er guns
Show on Jisho
1323
弱
weak
BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.
Show on Jisho
1324
溺
drowning
Darwin awards: The weakest of the *weak* will start drowning if put in several drops of *water*. (Do not confuse with {707})
Show on Jisho
1325
沸
seethe
*Water+dollars* = Jacuzzi. Think of all that #seething# and warm water!
Show on Jisho
1326
費
expense
A *dollar sign* next to an amount of *money* denotes an expense.
Show on Jisho
1327
第
No.
The No. 1 currency in the world is the *dollar*. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the *bamboo* represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (*bamboo* on top and the *dollar* on the bottom) is really a look at the future.
Show on Jisho
1328
弟
younger brother
#Younger brothers# are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little *horns* on him and the *dollar signs* on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.
Show on Jisho
1329
巧
adroit
To be *adroit* one must have mastered the #crafting# of #snares#.
Show on Jisho
1330
号
nickname
My nickname is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn't have put my *mouth* on that *bear trap*...
Show on Jisho
1331
朽
decay
Don't use wooden snares because, as the woodsman says, "They're prone to decay, and the catch gets away".
Show on Jisho
1332
誇
boast
The hunter's #boast#: I *say*, it was a "*big* *one*", but the *snare* broke and it got away. (credit to many others before)
Show on Jisho
1333
顎
chin
On the left, the primitive for crocodile (see {21666} for explanation). Thus: the *crocodile's* most prominent feature of its *head* is its long chin. (The tears that roll down over the chin come close second.) There it is, with its nostrils poking above the water, saying, 'come here, by the hairs on my chinny-chin chin.' [thx synewave]
Show on Jisho
1334
汚
dirty
Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.
Show on Jisho
1335
与
bestow
In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, *one* of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the *slingshot*.
Show on Jisho
1336
写
copy
A *crown* was *bestowed* to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.
Show on Jisho
1337
身
somebody
somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
Show on Jisho
1338
射
shoot
The aim of shooting is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone's body.
Show on Jisho
1339
謝
apologize
In the Wild West it's *shoot* first, apologize later, but in Japan the *words* come first - so polite!
Show on Jisho
1340
老
old man
An old man, wondering what it's like in a grave, *sits* in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with *soil*, the old man saves himself by flailing his *walking stick* in the air.
Show on Jisho
1341
考
consider
Before shooting an *old man* with a *slingshot*, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.
Show on Jisho
1342
孝
filial piety
+dilandau23: This *child* has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the *old man* on his shoulders. There is a picture of a statue depicting this here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filial_piety
Show on Jisho
1343
教
teach
In early Japan, *filial piety* was the cornerstone of education, and harsh *taskmasters* were employed to teach it.
Show on Jisho
1344
拷
torture
Pulling finger nails is considered to be the most common kind of torture.
Show on Jisho
1345
者
someone
I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for #ninja#: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who #endures# (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it's 者 who can 忍 great 拷!
Show on Jisho
1346
煮
boil
There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a *puppet* over an *oven fire*, to really make your victim feel the heat!
Show on Jisho
1347
著
renowned
if you put *flowers* on your *voodoo doll* that person will become renowned
Show on Jisho
1348
箸
chopsticks
I've always wanted to use *bamboo* chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this *love doll* will have to do.
Show on Jisho
1349
署
signature
Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the puppet, you should EYE over the puppet for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.
Show on Jisho
1350
暑
sultry
[from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you've ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing "Atsui! Atsui!" Here you are laying with your *love doll* under the hot *sun.* Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow "Atsui! It's so sultry!"
Show on Jisho
1351
諸
various
Imagine a wacky *variety* show on TV (i.e. *talk* show) where *puppets* are invited to *talk* about various topics. Here I use the expression "a *variety* show" to remember the particular keyword, and also keep it distinct from {562}.
Show on Jisho
1352
猪
boar
Boar hunting has been quite popular but under pressure from PETA, the hunters had to replace the real boar with a mechanical puppet for the pack of dogs to catch.
Show on Jisho
1353
渚
strand
I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn't upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!
Show on Jisho
1354
賭
gamble
People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.
Show on Jisho
1355
峡
gorge
A #gorge# is where God has cut into a *mountain* with a pair of *scissors*. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html
Show on Jisho
1356
狭
cramped
A *pack of wild dogs*, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by *Edward Scissors Hands*, who is very popular.
Show on Jisho
1357
挟
sandwiched
挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..
Show on Jisho
1358
頬
cheek
The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. Now the Joker isn't right in the head.
Show on Jisho
1359
追
chase
*Maestro*, coattails flapping wildly, is being #chase#d down the *road* by his fans.
Show on Jisho
1360
阜
large hill
The *maestro* lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over *ten* decibels without anyone giving a damn.
Show on Jisho
1361
師
expert
A *maestro* in a large auditorium with high *ceilings* is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his *towel* to wipe his brow.
Show on Jisho
1362
帥
commander
I like to recall commander in conjuntion with *expert.* Both are *maestros* with *towels* -- however, there is no upper limit (no *ceiling*) to what a commander can achieve in comparison to a mere expert.
Show on Jisho
1363
官
bureaucrat
No one likes classical music anymore. Our *Maestro* is here at *home* without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.
Show on Jisho
1364
棺
coffin
An excellent use of *wood* is to make coffins for *bureaucrat*s.
Show on Jisho
1365
管
pipe
Japanese *bureaucrats* send all their messages through an inter-office *bamboo* pipe system.
Show on Jisho
1366
父
father
Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.
Show on Jisho
1367
釜
cauldron
Whilst on holiday, my *father* was captured by cannibals and put in a *metal* cauldron.
Show on Jisho
1368
交
mingle
Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can`t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.
Show on Jisho
1369
効
merit (efficacy)
Once again Heisig makes a keyword that doesn't make much sense. The real meaning is #effect#/#efficacy# (take your pick). My dad tried out both wearing a top hat and doing some body-building for his muscles to see which was more efficacious .
Show on Jisho
1370
較
contrast
People *mingle* at parties. In contrast, *cars mingle* in traffic jams.
Show on Jisho
1371
校
exam
I "*WOOD MINGLE*", but I have an exam. Ha ha ha.
Show on Jisho
1372
足
leg
Tip : best avoid the generic image of a human leg, and use that of a *wooden leg*. As a primitive, the image of a pirate can easily stand for the *wooden leg*. As for this kanji, I think James Heisig provided a story, which worked well enough for me.
Show on Jisho
1373
促
stimulate
You stimulate a person by giving him a kick in the butt
Show on Jisho
1374
捉
nab
i felt a *finger* on my *leg* as someone tried to nab my wallet
Show on Jisho
1375
距
long-distance
You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts)
Show on Jisho
1376
路
path
I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths.
Show on Jisho
1377
露
dew
After the *rain* the *path* was covered with dew
Show on Jisho
1378
跳
hop
A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.
Show on Jisho
1379
躍
leap
The *turkey* with a *peg leg* is trying to leap across the canyon. He flaps his wings wildly and *feathers * fly but he doesn't make it.
Show on Jisho
1380
践
tread
Pirates must tread carefully when walking on *parade floats*, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their *wooden legs*.
Show on Jisho
1381
踏
step
You have to watch your step when moving your *leg* on a *watery day*.
Show on Jisho
1382
踪
trail
On the trail of the man with the *wooden leg* who stole from the *church* offering plate
Show on Jisho
1383
骨
skeleton
The most awesome pictograph ever: It's a guy going through an x-ray examination. The crown primitive depicts a glowing power field that goes from the top of this head down to the floor, progressively revealing his *skeleton*. Now, it's at the position of his shoulders, so everything below it is still *flesh*.
Show on Jisho
1384
滑
slippery
Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!
Show on Jisho
1385
髄
marrow
A *skeleton* is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he's going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still *possesses*.
Show on Jisho
1386
禍
calamity
Truely a calamity for an undead wedding, just as he may kiss the bride at the *altar*, he loses his *jawbone*
Show on Jisho
1387
渦
whirlpool
Grampa's flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!
Show on Jisho
1388
鍋
pot
A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a *metal* pot in the shape of a *skull* A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.
Show on Jisho
1389
過
overdo
In 'American History X' Edward Norton's character #overdoes# it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his *jawbone* open over the pavement of the *roadway* and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!
Show on Jisho
1390
阪
Heights
If you're scared of #Heights#, you don't want to stay at *The Pinnacle*; you are *anti-* *The Pinnacle*. Primitive: *The Pinnacle* is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with "mountain".
Show on Jisho
1391
阿
Africa
*Can* you see Africa from *The Pinnacle*? I *can*! I *can*!
Show on Jisho
1392
際
occasion
Many *rituals* are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the *peak* *rituals* (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion.
Show on Jisho
1393
障
hinder
At the #pinnacle# I was awarded a #badge# so big that it hinders my movement.
Show on Jisho
1394
隙
chink
They won't let me in *The Pinnacle*, but I can see a *little* bit of *sun* through this *little* #chink# in the wall. Hmm, maybe I could make this #chink# bigger...
Show on Jisho
1395
随
follow
This story is about lemmings. when the first takes a road that falls off a pinnacle, the rest follow as if possessed.
Show on Jisho
1396
陪
auxiliary
When you climb the *pinnacle* you'll need to take a *muzzle* of auxiliary oxygen.
Show on Jisho
1397
陽
sunshine
A kid is perched on a *pinnacle* with his *piggy bank*. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people's eyes, far below.
Show on Jisho
1398
陳
line up
Hikers line up to get to the top of that great *pinnacle* of the *East*... Mount Fuji. Seriously, they really do! ...probably the only mountain in the world with a queue at the top
Show on Jisho
1399
防
ward off
A giant compass is *The Pinnacle*'s self-#defense# system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders. (The Fellowship of the Ring ward off the direction of pinnacle because saruman)
Show on Jisho
1400
附
affixed
A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.
Show on Jisho
1401
院
Inst.
The Inst. of Kanji.Koohii. It's where we all try to get to the *pinnacle* of Japanese by *perfecting* our kanji writing skills.
Show on Jisho
1402
陣
camp
At the #pinnacle# of Mt. Everest, you can *camp*, but you cannot find a parking place for your #car#!
Show on Jisho
1403
隊
regiment (party)
Every regiment of *The Pinnacle*'s army is lead by a *Miss Piggy* with a *viking* helmet on.
Show on Jisho
1404
墜
crash
One of the members of our air force *regiment* has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the *ground*.
Show on Jisho
1405
降
descend
"Sunglasses-missing-one-lens" is obviously the *monocle*. The proper, high-class way to descend *The Pinnacle* is wearing a *monocle* with your *walking legs* splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.
Show on Jisho
1406
階
story(storey)
*All* buildings of *The Pinnacle* are multi-#storey#. They don't have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses *all* the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each #storey#!
Show on Jisho
1407
陛
highness
His Highness, the main man at the Pinnacle, often compares those who live outside the city's walls to dirt.
Show on Jisho
1408
隣
neighboring
All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.
Show on Jisho
1409
隔
isolate
Do you remember the poor insect in {1044}? Actually, it was not dissolved - it was beamed right into the *pinnacle* prison for committing the crime of disturbing a *photographer preparing for a snapshot* and now lives isolated until the end of its three days long life... (note: 隔てる (へだてる) also means to #disturb ones view#)
Show on Jisho
1410
隠
conceal
People of the *pinnacle* learned to conceal their nature with *calm* demeanors, though in their *hearts* they are *vultures* and *witches* (broom)
Show on Jisho
1411
堕
degenerate
Any attempt to *possess* the *pinnacle* will degenerate into a land ("*ground*") war.
Show on Jisho
1412
陥
collapse
*The Pinnacle* is actually *bound up* by supports from *olden times*. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse.
Show on Jisho
1413
穴
hole
A black hole is a "House of Infinity". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways "8", but here we have a Japanese "8" instead.
Show on Jisho
1414
空
empty
If you craft a giant black hole, the universe will be empty
Show on Jisho
1415
控
withdraw
If you find yourself in a fight with a karate master with no weapons or martial art skills, just your *empty fingers*, you should withdraw because 空手 (karate="empty hand") is more powerful than 控 (="empty fingers").
Show on Jisho
1416
突
stab
When you stab something you often leave a big hole.
Show on Jisho
1417
究
research
Scientiest are researching , and have already found *nine* black *holes* !
Show on Jisho
1418
窒
plug up
I'm pretty sure Heisig wrote the whole book just so he could make this joke.
Show on Jisho
1419
窃
stealth
I picture a stealthy thief cutting a round hole in the glass window to quietly unlock it.
Show on Jisho
1420
窟
cavern
The entrance to the cavern tavern is little more than a *hole* in the wall, but inside the place is such a maze of caverns that they have to stick a *flag* over the *exit* or you'd never find your way out.
Show on Jisho
1421
窪
depression
A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.
Show on Jisho
1422
搾
squeeze
(Thanks DrJones) You squeeze the teats of the cow with your *fingers* but it's your first try and you don't have any milk come through the *holes*, so you take a *saw* and cut the teats to make bigger *holes*. Poor cow, this story squeezes my heart. Very simple visual image makes this an easy kanji to remember. Just picture that you SQUEEZE your FINGERS going through the HOLE in the handle of the SAW. You then SQUEEZE your FINGERS tight to use the SAW to cut a HOLE.
Show on Jisho
1423
窯
kiln
Be sure to put a *hole* in that ceramic *sheep* before you put it over the *fire*. Otherwise, it'll just explode in the kiln. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.)
Show on Jisho
1424
窮
hard up
Ok, picture a HOLE (well, more a pit trap) that SOMEBODY (well, a hunter with a BOW) just fell in. He's dangling over the HOLE holding onto his BOW across it. SOMEBODY finds it's HARD to get UP out of the HOLE. That great visual image should grant mastery of this kanji.
Show on Jisho
1425
探
grope
I don't know why, but this is a pictograph of someone groping about in the dark (with his fingers, obviously) for his beloved wooden paper punch.
Show on Jisho
1426
深
deep
Made a hole with a paper punch in a tree, so deep that water started flowing out.
Show on Jisho
1427
丘
hill
Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the *axe* planted on top of a hill.
Show on Jisho
1428
岳
Point
This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it's surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as Point, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It's as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height.
Show on Jisho
1429
兵
soldier
Soldiers specially designed for combat in the #hill#s have got their lower body replaced by that of a mountain goat. Picture them hopping up the hills like silly little centaurs with their new #animal legs#!
Show on Jisho
1430
浜
seacoast
Imagine Normandy after the strikes on the beach. The *water* of the entire seacoast dyed red with the blood of thousands of *soldiers*.
Show on Jisho
1431
糸
thread
I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I've opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as {1363} and {1364}.
Show on Jisho
1432
織
weave
Spiderman play the kazoo magically and the thread will weave itself.
Show on Jisho
1433
繕
darning
After a day being *virtuouos* and keeping the city safe, *Spiderman*'s outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do
Show on Jisho
1434
縮
shrink
After spending the night at an *inn*, *spider man* discovered to his dismay that his costume had #shrunk# in the wash, and no longer fit!
Show on Jisho
1435
繁
luxuriant
Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When *Venom* realized he couldn't beat *Spider-Man* in a fair fight, he showed his *cleverness* by spraying venom all over Spider-Man's luxuriant garden.
Show on Jisho
1436
縦
vertical
When *Spider-man* does his amazing vertical wall climbing, a throng of photographers *accompanies* him to get a good shot of the action.
Show on Jisho
1437
緻
fine
This kanji shows *Spiderman* giving a dress of the #finest# thread to his girlfriend. Of course, the real purpose of the gift is to get his girlfriend to *doth* him.
Show on Jisho
1438
線
line
Japan's train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station
Show on Jisho
1439
綻
come apart at the seams
*Spiderman* is so *determined* to catch criminals that he doesn't notice his costume is #coming apart at the seams#. The Daily Bugle will love this! "Spider-pervert terrorizes city!"
Show on Jisho
1440
締
tighten
The *sovereign* appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a *thread* around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn't like, she starts pulling the *thread* and tightens it around his throat.
Show on Jisho
1441
維
fiber
Hey, *Spidey*! Eat that *turkey* if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey *threads*, don't ya?
Show on Jisho
1442
羅
gauze
The *eyes* on Spiderman's mask are made of carbon *fibre* gauze. Light, strong and see-through.
Show on Jisho
1443
練
practice
[+ skinnyneo] *Spiderman* visits the *East* to practice his swinging skills. All those Asian cities with skyscrapers and low crime rates make it easy for him to practice
Show on Jisho
1444
緒
thong
A thong is no more than a *thread* used by *someone* as underwear!
Show on Jisho
1445
続
continue
Even though Peter Parker has become *Spiderman*, he continues to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer.
Show on Jisho
1446
絵
picture
There's never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?
Show on Jisho
1447
統
overall
According to Greek mythology, there's a *thread* *alloted* to everyone, and its length is the overall determinant of your fate.
Show on Jisho
1448
絞
strangle
Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.
Show on Jisho
1449
給
salary
*Spiderman* wanted to be a #salary#man, but the suit just didn't *fit* him.
Show on Jisho
1450
絡
entwine
When threads become entwined, *each* *thread* is tangled to another.
Show on Jisho
1451
結
tie
I'm wearing my *Spiderman* tie today for *good luck*.
Show on Jisho
1452
終
end
*Winter* spells the end of every *spider*'s life.
Show on Jisho
1453
級
class
This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a "class of students" or "classroom," but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend's answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.
Show on Jisho
1454
紀
chronicle
worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!
Show on Jisho
1455
紅
crimson
Spiderman crafted a crimson costume to fight crime in.
Show on Jisho
1456
納
settlement
*Spider-Man* was working as a surgeon's assistant. By accident, he threw his spider webs *inside* the patient, causing his death. Fortunately, the hospital reached an out-of-court #settlement# with the victim's family.
Show on Jisho
1457
紡
spinning
*Spiderman* can #spin# his webs in any *direction*.
Show on Jisho
1458
紛
distract
Due to the #distract#ions of being a super-hero, *spiderman* can only work *part*-time. (variation on ayoung24's story)
Show on Jisho
1459
紹
introduce
Peter Parker did a terrible job of *seducing* MJ. *Spiderman* however, *seduced* her as soon as they were first #introduced#.
Show on Jisho
1460
経
sutra
The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a *spool* that is holding the *threads* together.
Show on Jisho
1461
紳
sire
Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire.
Show on Jisho
1462
約
promise
Anytime *Spiderman* breaks a promise, Aunt May hits him one over with her *ladle*.
Show on Jisho
1463
細
dainty
*Spider-Man* used to just be a dainty, *brainy* nerd.
Show on Jisho
1464
累
accumulate
When you accumulate knowledge in your *brain*, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of *thread* tangled together. The more knowledge you accumulate the more *threads* you throw into the mix!!
Show on Jisho
1465
索
cord
(modified akrodha's great story) VENOM has been captured by scientists and is being experimented on: they forced a CROWN of NEEDLES on his head and attached it to multiple electrical cords, which are connected to a big machine.
Show on Jisho
1466
総
general
*Spiderman* could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the *public*'s *heart*.
Show on Jisho
1467
綿
cotton
Cotton is the preferred *thread* for making *white* *towels*.
Show on Jisho
1468
絹
silk
[silk] #Silk# is a *thread* that a larvae produces from its *mouth* to involve its *body*.
Show on Jisho
1469
繰
winding
After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.
Show on Jisho
1470
継
inherit
A poor chinese fisherman could expect to #inherit#: the *thread* for his pole, a *hook* for catching something to eat, and some *rice* to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006)
Show on Jisho
1471
緑
green
*Spiderman's* nemesis the Green Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a *broom* and is throwing *grains of rice* instead of bombs.
Show on Jisho
1472
縁
affinity
There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the *pig* was to take a *broom* and sweep up all of *Spiderman's leftover threads* after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.
Show on Jisho
1473
網
netting
*Spiderman* traps The Rhino under the *hood* of his famous netting, where even Rhino's *horns* can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even *perish* in there.
Show on Jisho
1474
緊
tense
You'd be tense too if you were a *slave* and your owner removed the *threads* covering your *crotch*.
Show on Jisho
1475
紫
purple
*Venom* starts to choke on a *spoon*. He's about to get it out, when you manage to *stop* the *spoon* from getting out, so he turns purple, as he chokes, and dies.
Show on Jisho
1476
縛
truss
Because people are so afraid of the procedure, *string* has to be used by the *acunpunturist* to truss up his victims, er, patients.
Show on Jisho
1477
縄
straw rope
The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that's left of the rope are some torn *threads*, and the *unbound tortoise* is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not "eels". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in {537} to refer to the simplified form of dragon as "eels". It is much better to call the right half of this character an "unbound tortoise".)
Show on Jisho
1478
幼
infancy
In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a *cocoon*, as it doesn't yet have any *power* of its own.
Show on Jisho
1479
後
behind
#After# a grub *goes* through the *cocoon* stage, it leaves its *walking legs* behind for a life of flight.
Show on Jisho
1480
幽
faint
The villagers haven't the #faint#est idea that giant *coccoons* resting in the secluded *mountain* are soon to hatch.
Show on Jisho
1481
幾
how many
At the Mexican *fiesta*, there is a *coccoon* eating competition. How many *coccoons* can one *person* eat? No one has managed more than two before giving up...
Show on Jisho
1482
機
mechanism
An *abacus* is a mechanism made of *wood* used to calculate *how many* 'anythings'
Show on Jisho
1483
畿
capital suburbs
This keyword refers to Japan's Kinki Region, a historic name for present-day Kansai. 近畿 きんき Just *how many rice fields* are in the capital suburbs? (The kinky (Kinki) *people* are hidden in the fields so you can't see them)
Show on Jisho
1484
玄
mysterious
What could be more mysterious than a *cocoon* in a *top hat* trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: *GANDALF*).
Show on Jisho
1485
畜
livestock
This *mysterious* *rice field* grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!
Show on Jisho
1486
蓄
amass
One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field.
Show on Jisho
1487
弦
bowstring
A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring.
Show on Jisho
1488
擁
hug
A *mysterious* *turkey* with human *finger*s wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!
Show on Jisho
1489
滋
nourishing
Water is doubly mysterious. It`s in all our nourishment...and yet, it`s really not nourishing at all.
Show on Jisho
1490
慈
mercy
Mercy comes from the doubly mysterious heart of God.
Show on Jisho
1491
磁
magnet
A magnet is a *rock* with two sides; one that *mysteriously* pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops' story)
Show on Jisho
1492
系
lineage
(Primitive: *DNA*, a drop of looong spiraled thread that is the key to your #lineage#).
Show on Jisho
1493
係
person in charge
the person in charge usually must come from a long standing *lineage* of persons in charge.
Show on Jisho
1494
孫
grandchild
Your *child* continues the family *lineage* by passing on your *DNA*, giving you a grandchild.
Show on Jisho
1495
懸
suspend
In a very racist *prefecture* of Japan, they screen everyone's *DNA*. If they find out you are of a different *lineage*, they rip out your *heart* and suspend it in the Hall of Shame.
Show on Jisho
1496
遜
modest
My parents aren't at all modest about their *grandchildren*, at every opportunity they take them on the *road* showing them off to their friends!
Show on Jisho
1497
却
instead
[instead; on the contrary; rather] *Gone* is the time for *stamps* - use e-mail #instead#.
Show on Jisho
1498
脚
shins
shins are the *part of the body* that Japanese traditionally sit on *instead* of their asses.
Show on Jisho
1499
卸
wholesale
If you need *horseshoes* (shoes that fit your *horse*'s *footprint*), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste *stamps* in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.
Show on Jisho
1500
御
honorable
When buying wholesale the honorable thing to do would be to wait in line like everyone else.
Show on Jisho
1501
服
clothing
It's customary to cover the *flesh* with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they're not bigger than a *stamp* that just covers your *crotch*.
Show on Jisho
1502
命
fate
When you're born, your fate is measured, *fitted*, and *stamped* onto your soul. Good luck defying it.
Show on Jisho
1503
令
orders
"These are your #orders#," declares the general at the *meeting* as he stamps them with his *chop-seal*. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one's they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.)
Show on Jisho
1504
零
zero
The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.
Show on Jisho
1505
齢
age
At my age I still have not lost TEETH, so at the restaurant i can still ORDER what I want!
Show on Jisho
1506
冷
cool
To keep your water cool, just *order* some *ice*.
Show on Jisho
1507
領
jurisdiction
Jurisdiction just makes me think of "sheriff". So my story takes place in the jurisdiction of some sheriff. The sheriff goes into a bar and calls the waitress. He looks at one of those "WANTED" posters, with the portrait of a criminal he's been trying to catch for such a long time. When asked for his *orders*, still staring intently at the picture, he says : "I want the *head* of that guy on a plate, yep, right now!". The waitress scurried away and brought him just that : *orders* with a *head*.
Show on Jisho
1508
鈴
small bell
Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.
Show on Jisho
1509
勇
courage
I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young *man* has to show his courage. They then receive a *chopseal* which is a mark of their courage.
Show on Jisho
1510
湧
bubble up
The *courageous* man who went into the *water* to save a drowning victim couldn't be seen, except by the air that #bubbled up#.
Show on Jisho
1511
通
traffic
I bounce down the *road* on my *pogo stick*, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a *chop-seal* is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could *utilize* it as a *pogo stick*). [Edit: *pogo stick* also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530]
Show on Jisho
1512
踊
jump
The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a *pogo stick* tied to his *leg* to jump further.
Show on Jisho
1513
疑
doubt
(Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. `Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.` cool `and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong` ....` please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.` `lion feeding time is. bla bla` You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo. DELETED BY ACCIDENT 31 12
Show on Jisho

1520
危
dangerous
You're *bound up* by ropes to an *unlucky* person. It's dangerous, because whatever happens to him will happen to you too.
Show on Jisho
1521
宛
address
For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese *mailbox*, it automatically lights up in the *evening*, and has a biometric *fingerprint* scanner.---Each *house*'s address, even if it's hard to see in the *evening*, is like its own unique *fingerprint*.

柳
willow
I ordered a willow *tree* off Amazon but when it arrived it was covered in postage *stamps*. I try to peel them off but it ends up leaving a papery mess and cheapifies the willow's appearance. Luckily I kept a *receipt*.

bartending
At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the *whiskey* by pouring it from a *ladle*, like one would from the punch bowl.

1537
酎
hooch
While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.
Show on Jisho
1538
酵
fermentation
Since *filial piety* is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a *whiskey bottle* is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will.

1546

waver
The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle. Furthermore they've bored me! For the right primitive: Red Bull (the energy drink). Can be mixed with alcohol and gives you wi- uh, horns. Coincidentally, also the name of the Indian CHIEFTAN in frame 2906. (Thanks Katsuo).

1563

overflow
When *water* overflows it is usually because someone was not properly *overseeing* the task. Image: A mother talking on the phone, *overseeing* the drawing her kid's bath, boiling something on the stove, and breaking up a fight between two of the kids. Something is bound to overflow.

Show on Jisho
1565
藍
indigo
Traditionally, 青 {青} could be used to describe blue OR green. However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑. This kanji is the "blue" counterpart of {緑}. Story: The *overseer*, master of the slaves, wore a cloak dyed with indigo, and *flowers* in his hair. indigo *flowers* have to be *overseen* because they are often picked for their beauty

飽
sated

Show on Jisho
1593
既
previously
Distinguish from {501}. Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the *waitress* gives you unwashed *silver*ware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.

1616
壁
wall
Primitive for #Ketchup#: When the taste is too *spicy* your *mouth* has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white *flag* of surrender. But unlike war , putting #Ketchup# on it will usually solve the problem. #Wall#(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the *ground* and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
Show on Jisho
1617

holed gem
This kanji shows a policeman with a #holed gem# (which can be thought of as *jewelry*, I guess), but he thinks it's a doughnut. For some reason though, he liked his doughnuts with ketchup on them, so he added some, and tried to take a bite. He lost a few teeth on the process.

new

1626
叫
shout
There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.

Spiderman counts in his new cover band singing cheesy golden oldies. 1,2,3,*4*..Lets twist again...
Show on Jisho
1628
収
income
Prostitutes can make a veritable *cornucopia* of income by using their *crotches* -- they put the "come" in "income." (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like {906} or {893}) #STROKE ORDER WARNING#: The order in which the cornucopia primitive is written is altered here. First the long vertical bar, then the L part in either one or two strokes (this seems to vary in different reference materials).

A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food

1630
碑
tombstone
There is a grave of a *lowly* man with a tombstone made of a simple, small *stone*. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the *stone*, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as *lowly* as I once was”.
Show on Jisho
1631
陸
land
My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a *pinnacle*, which the newly-awakened *rice-seedlings* who are still stuck in the *ground* can see. Could it be the Promised Land?
Show on Jisho
1632

Show on Jisho

勢
forces
{1513} The *rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil* gather *round* in a circle. Their combined *power* forces them out of the ground at last.
Show on Jisho
1634
熱
heat
{疑} The *rice-seedlings* (newly freed from the ground but with *soil* still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle *around* an *oven fire*. They need to heat up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?) ねつ 【熱】fever,cold
Show on Jisho
1635
菱
diamond
{1513} Deciding to use the diamond-shaped water caltrop *flower* as cover/protection, the *rice-seedlings* with their *walking legs* (now free from soil), can start their journey.

陵

A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.

The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.
Show on Jisho
1639
刻
engrave
This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with *sabres*, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto *acorns*, and throw the *acorns* to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the *acorn* and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead. DWARF most famous engraving. An acorn -.-

I asked my teacher what this strange *word* meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an *acorn* at me!

Show on Jisho
1645
寒
cold
Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a *stalk of celery* and a *pair of animal legs* slipping and sliding clumsily around the *ice*, and never able to leave the *house*. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.

The A/C wasn't making the house *cold* because the filters had been #blocked up# with *dirt*.

(thanks chamcham) A graduate student in anthropology tells the University that he plans to defer his studies for a year, and instead conduct "field research" on the grass-skirt-wearing native women on the island of Jou.

1649

lot

Show on Jisho
1650

Barley is a very cheap grain, and it's not really worth spending time to harvest. Therefore, scientists have genetically engineered it to grow *walking legs* once the grain is *grown up* and mature, so it can harvest itself.

1661
責
blame
This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the *oyster grew so big*, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, #blaming# his blind greed for their poverty.

volume

constitution

Since its creation, it's gotten *bigger and bigger*, and it's even grown a *pair of eyes*, as well as a *beating heart*. Naturally the Emperor tries to keep this hidden from the public, but what will they do once the constitution-monster becomes big enough to destroy the palace?

The god was infuriated and yelled at him "HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!". The End.

There's a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/#Korean# relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the *misty* eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their *lockets* with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".

1783
幹
tree trunk
by astridtops - In the rainy *mist*, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the *umbrella* he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains *dry*! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->#TT# ->#T#onari no #T#otoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき

Show on Jisho
1785
宇
eaves
Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.
Show on Jisho
1786
余
too much
You hang an *umbrella* upside-down on a hook of the #scales# and fill it with *little* *potatoes*. No luck: it weights #too much#.
Show on Jisho
1787
除
exclude
To become a member of *The Pinnacle*, they test you on a *scale*. If you weigh *too much*, they #exclude# you.
Show on Jisho
1788
徐
gradually
You can't expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit *going* to the *scale* to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.

Picture them in winter all *bundled* up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the *zoo* who at least are *bundled* in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.

1801

Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of "The *Awl and the Sabre*". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an *awl* against a *sabre*! She used to work all day with that *awl*. However, the bandit using the *sabre* had no skill. And thus the *awl* beat the *sabre*. And from there the saying goes : "The *sabre* is powerless against the *awl*, if one can't use the *sabre*."
